name: Anonymous
com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

name: Anonymous
com:
Most overrated game in history? I just finished this mediocre test of patience, and I have some thoughts about it that are probably gonna piss the fanboys off.

Yeah I know this is a beloved game and all, but I’m here to tell you that title has not been earned.

First off, I have to talk about the idea of difficulty for the sake of difficulty. This is objectively bad game design, as it doesn’t allow the player to meaningfully overcome challenges in a controlled manner. The difficulty of this game spikes incredibly after the first world when all of a sudden they throw this fucking mine cart mechanic at you, and it’s nearly impossible to control.

Second, there’s literally no reason for any of the levels. There’s nothing to be gained from any of them, no sub plots, no actual point to donkey Kong and diddy infiltrating factories or driving a mine cart down the rails of an abandoned mine. What’s my motivation for the levels?

Third, bonuslevels? I don’t get anything for completing them? Not like a new weapon or ability or anything? What’s the point? To watch the completion percentage number go up. Okay???

Fourth, speaking of, donkey and diddy don’t learn anything from their adventures. No new abilities, no character development, no extra knowledge that unlocks paths in the levels, they just stay the same the whole time.

Fifth, I can only get hit once!?!! I’m a giant gorilla, the king of the jungle, and I get taken out by TOUCHING A BEAVER??? Makes no fucking sense. They could have at least included a health bar. The one hit shit is nonsensical and only exists to add artificial difficulty.

Sixth. Running and jumping in every level. I can roll too. No actual attacks though. Again, king of the jungle, I should be able to rip a man in half with my bare hands, but I’m stuck doing gymnastics.

Seven, funky kong could have dropped me off at k rool right from the start. Making all of the levels pointless. Massive plot hole

2. KI cashed in on the Street Fighter and Mortal Kombat boom, but failed to ride the next wave which was the 3D fighters. A 2d fighter couldn't stand out against Tekken, Virtua Fighter, and all the others.

3. N64 fans are Nintendo fanboys, and Smash Bros is what grabbed their attention.

4. KI isn't good enough to stand out on its own outside of the toned down Mortal Kombat aestetic.

com: "Retro" ends after the 6th gen and the 7th gen is where modernity begins: it's the gen of widescreen, HD, photorealism, standardization, "hollywoodization", as well as other hideous practices. This cutoff line is actually very straightforward when you realize how free of all this shit the 6th gen was; no wonder normalfags can't stand games from it already.

>>9484791
>Wrong. So backwards compatibility makes games not retro anymore? Ps3 plays ps1. I guess ps1 isn't retro now. Derp.
Let me rephrase it, for anons with poor reading comprehension.
Any consoles released after 1st January 2000 aren't retro. Games for these consoles released after this date would still be retro.
Final Fantasy 9 would still be a retro game since it was developed for and released for the PS1, a console that was first released in late 1994, despite the game itself being released in mid-2000.
So would Digimon World 3, despite being released in 2003.
For PC games the cut-off would be 31st December 2004, with some exceptions. Half-Life 2 can't really be considered retro, while Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines could, since it inherits so much from 2000's Deus Ex.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>9481442
>Have you ever noticed that the Turbografx is actually just a black PC Engine with a big tumor attached to its left and rear sides?
Funny enough that redesign may have actually killed the console. NEC was targeting a Christmas 88 release but the sentiment that >>9483082 America needs a bigger device pushed them redesign the console, they took 7 months to design, prototype, produce and ship the new console, by the time they arrived for sale in summer of 89 the folks at Sega had already launched their Genesis system in America 2 weeks in advance and planned an aggressive ad campaign to claiming the TG16 was weak in comparison to the Genesis. Since PCe was already big in Japan and beating Sega there they pre-assumed victory and skimped on heavy marketing of the TG16 in favor of over production to meet a non-existent demand. That meant shelves full of unsold TG16's and people asking when the new Sega would be in stock... if they had the most powerful system on the market for 7 months, getting in peoples homes, spreading via word of mouth well, maybe the big rivalry of the 90's would be Nintendo vs NEC and not Sega.

>>9483134
much appreciated, although after slaving away at these games for three years i'd consider myself mildly competent at best lol. it's been quite a while since i frequented ta.p
it's been long enough that i'm already starting to forget the things that helped me succeed so i'll just regurgitate the advice i usually give to people in your position:
>read tgm.tips, the tetris wiki, and old tetrisconcept threads like they're your personal bible (disc*rd is occasionally helpful if you're willing to use the fucking thing and can handle it responsibly)
>watch tgm superplays on youtube at 0.5x speed and analyze what each player does while trying to predict their next move - if they do something different, ask yourself why they made that decision and if it was the better play in hindsight. you can't think piece-by-piece, you have to consider how your stack is going to affect you in the long run
>grind 20g, do it in a clone like texmaster or with the 20g cheat. it sounds terrifying, but a common suggestion i saw was to grind death in tap until you can get used to the lower level speeds and i actually recommend that, if you can hit death 300 you can probably get tgm1 gm. ars seems scary until you realize it's restrictive enough there are only a few places you can put down a piece at any given time, which makes it easier to stack - 20g restricts your options further, it's mostly a matter of learning *how* to put the pieces where you want
>get used to abusing irs as much as you can
>i'm awful at not choking, but my advice: misdropping once is not the end of the world, look for downstacking opportunities and take them as soon as you can. 20g and death in particular will force you to git gud at this
>this isn't too relevant until you start time attacking, but avoid clearing singles since it wastes time
i can't fucking find when i did it but it took me at least 3 or 4 months to go from breaking level 500 to getting gm, keep chipping away at it and you'll get it soon enough

ah shit. in that case, grinding death and shirase helped me improve my stacking speed to the point where tgm1 20g feels almost serene in comparison - granted, neither of those modes teach you how to stack cleanly for tetrises, but i think going for death m + 20g gm in tgm1 is a good goal to set if you're trying to break the 11 minute barrier, eventually 20g stacking will become second nature and you'll actually feel like you're in control most of the time
if you can, make recordings of your gameplay and analyze those too to see what you could have done here - there's a tc thread where people made fucking spreadsheets writing down all of their section times, line clears and level stops (https://tetrisconcept.net/threads/analyze-videos-of-your-gameplay.2821/) seeing what they could improve on. are you not making it under 11 minutes because you spent 15 seconds trying to clear a line on level 499? did you make way too many singles after level 500? it sounds boring as hell but it's a really good way of figuring out what you need to improve on. watch out for level stops in particular, they can really add up over the course of a run and there's no sound indicator for them until ti

com:
Someone posted this image on /ck/ and it reminded me how much I hated pre-rendered backgrounds in 3d games as a kid. Growing up with the SNES and Genesis, I remember the first game we got in 3D was Mario 64, which gives you a very physical, tactile environment where your character interacts with every surface and edge. Then you play something like Zelda or Final Fantasy of the same generation and you get these weird environments where you never feel like your character collides with anything, like your character is running around in a clear box with invisible walls and there is a background superimposed via green screen. As I got older and understood why it was made that way I appreciated the effort and extra detail allowed by it, but as a kid it always bugged me and still does to a degree.

Did this bother anyone else as a kid or just me?
